ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned in detail about the selection of films, and developed general purpose skills of close-analysis on film. Improved ability to write in detail on craft and themes of film.
Ability to watch complex art films with a critical eye. Also how to apply principles of close analysis we discussed in class to high level film papers.
I strengthened my ability to analyze films and pull out the ways that it uses things like cinematography and music in order to convey different things. Its becoming more and more second nature.
Loved learning more about film, cinematography and direction of film
I developed the ability to break films down with a keener more analytic eye, and get even deeper into the content and other film techniques that a variety of both recent and historic films.
Close analysis of film, a study of film theory

I learned how to look more closely at different components of film, especially elements such as sound that aren't as obvious when analyzing a scene. Discussions helped me think more critically about the subtle messages conveyed by the specific choices made in films.
A completely new and utterly exciting way of engaging with film.
Got to watch a broad range of films and discuss them analytically

I gained a deeper appreciation for the ways in which a film can make visual arguments, sociopolitical arguments, and narrative arguments using the formal tools of filmmaking. This class has enhanced my enjoyment of every movie.
looked at a series of films in close analysis
I learned about new movies
Storytelling and close analysis of film
I expanded my knowledge of close analysis from what I had learned in intro to film.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professors are fantastic, and the TA's are incredibly helpful. Very fun to attend, with a great selection of films. Sometimes (on account of the weekly presentation format) there can be too much of fellow classmates talking and too little of the teaching staff (professors + TAs), which is a shame because the teaching staff is incredibly knowledgable.

I think many of the weaknesses of this course can be chalked up to the virtual semester. I believe that there were too many people in the course for it to be taught successfully, and the amount of people vying for attention just lead to an overall lower level of engagement. 
The strengths of the course are its teachers and TFs. They helped guide conversation and forced students to approach the films in new and interesting ways.

This class has a great curriculum and two excellent professors. Unfortunately, it was not structured well over Zoom to promote students' learning. Too many people were accepted into the class, especially a lot of graduate students, so on top of an already decreased level of engagement over Zoom, it was difficult to participate naturally in the discussions. I think these problems will be fixed in person, but most people only spoke when it was their week to give a presentation.

I think the choice of films for the course was very good. They were very diverse and were all excellent in different ways. However, I do think more modern films would maintain engagement in the class. Also, having students presenting 4 times over the course of the semester is unnecessarily stressful. I think the class shouldve just been broken up into groups of maybe 15 and had smaller discussions about the films each week.
It felt disorganized at first bc the professors didnt know how to translate the class to a virtual format. But they took our feedback into consideration and made huge changes that improved the class

I thought that the course was great in that we were asked to present on multiple of the movies during the semester, and the presentations helped me dive into the movies more and allowed me to practice my close analysis skills. A weakness I'd say was that the class was a little too big making it hard to participate in the discussion.
I definitely think the size of the seminar was perhaps too big but regardless, the discussions were facilitated very well. Professors and TAs were so caring and dedicated

Strengths: absolutely amazing professors and TAs. They wre the kindest, most wonderful and understanding people throughout the course. The films we were required to watch were also a strength as they were quite diverse and introduced me to so many films that I otherwise would have never encountered. Weaknesses: its format. Halfway through the course, they were still changing the way we were doing a class. It was difficult structuring a class with about 40 people around what was meant to be a much smaller discussion seminar. At first, everyone had to do a presentation every week on the movie that was assigned. It evolved into rotating groups for presentations. Also, some readings were not provided and we had to get them elsewhere.

You learn how to authentically engage with film on an 10000000 IQ level. Moira is also a complete gem and expanded the boundaries of what I thought I knew about cinema. The discussions were so interesting that they often carried over 2 HOURS after class had finished, with many students staying behind to witness the nuclear-grade analyses that were being discussed. Sadly, however, this was quite unfair to the many students who had other time commitments. This course seriously hits.
Wonderful and engaging professors. It was a large format for a seminar which meant that several people dominated the discussion. I would have liked the class to be smaller

Strengths: A syllabus of amazing films. Weaknesses: It was a seminar taught like a lecture! There were so many people in the class that it was almost impossible to meaningfully "participate," which was made even more difficult by the fact that the entire class was on Zoom. I wish they had just split us up into two classes rather than smush us into one giant section.

Over zoom, it could be a bit difficult to get large class engagement for over 50 people. Class presentations were a nice way to facilitate class participation but at times presentations took a lot of the discussion time of the class.

Due to covid, there was the need to adjust to find a good way of structuring the class, but after finding that way, things worked very well. There were not too many opportunities to gain feedback as there was only one paper to get feedback on: the midterm with the final later on that may or may not have feedback, the class is over so im not sure if we will get it later or not. Other feedback was simply people saying nice point during your class presentation.

The regular seminar format of this course is a strength. However, the large class size and zoom seminars made participation difficult. The teaching team is knowledgeable and passionate about the films and readings and that comes across in each class. In person screenings and discussion will be great for this class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Spending the first hour watching hastily prepared student presentations via zoom can sometimes make students check-out. Might not be as much of a problem in person.
This course was not built for virtual engagement, and although the teachers tried to adapt it, I think it hurt the course more than it helped.

The class presentations were too long and difficult to engage with if you weren't the one presenting. This class should have split into two sections and run by the two professors and TFs separately to create more space for student engagement.
N/A

I'm unsure if this would have been the case with this class, but when FILM 150 was conducted in person, the whole class gathered to watch the required movies together in a theater on campus. Again, I'm unsure if this would have been the case for FILM 320 normally. Because of COVID, there were no arrangements to watch any of the films as a class together. If there was a way to organize class-wide film screenings, that would greatly improve the class.

Group presentation organisation outside of class lacked some structure, and the 10 minute rule on class presentations was often hard to fully monitor. However, these problems were mostly resolved by the end of the semester.
Watched the films independently instead of group screenings

The class was simply too big for anyone student to feel like they could participate meaningfully. In fact, I often felt like I was in a lecture taught by my fellow film majors for the first half and an "idea showing off contest" for the second half. Online classes are tough, but by combining the numbers of a lecture with the format of a seminar, Close Analysis of Film made online class even more difficult.
I think a bit more structure between the student presentations and class discussions might help. At times it felt like discussions could get carried away by a handful of students.
Virtual lectures simply could not replace in-person ones.

The weekly presentations allowed for each person to bring their point of view to the discussion. The conversations in the chat and out loud allowed for interesting discussion and participation, but could sometimes be confusing. It took some time to figure out the format and structure of the weekly presentations which led to the class feeling inconsistent over the course of the semester, but it got better as time went on.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!! Even if not a film major, this will put you on to some incredible directors, and Moira/John are just such a delight to take class with.
I would, but only if you were a film major. If you aren't a film major, and just want to learn the language of cinema, definitely take Film 150

I would recommend this course to another student, but only if they get to take it in person. I don't doubt that this class is usually fabulous for film majors, but online it was really messy and hard to engage with. A large proportion of your grade is participation, but it was almost impossible to participate with so many people together on the Zoom calls. John and Moira are the best of the best in terms of film professors, though.

I would definitely recommend it for students who are real fans of film only just because the material is not geared toward casual film watchers and they would probably have a hard time maintaining interest.
Yes!
Yes, because it helps with your close analysis skills, and you get a watch a big variety of fantastic movies that are highly diverse and very intellectually stimulating.
Yes! It will definitely get you to explore films you otherwise would not have! Also, highly recommended for cinephiles

I'm not sure if I would've taken it if it wasn't a requirement for the film major, so I'm on the fence about whether I'd recommend it. I think I would've had a completely different experience if it'd been in person, so I'd probably recommend it to another student as an in-person class. It was just extremely disorganized at first as they tried figuring out how to adapt to the Zoom format. But honestly, I ended up really loving it. The professors and TAs are the absolute best, so I'd probably take the class again just for them.

YES YES YES YES film major or not this course will completely change the way you engage with cinema. Totally reaffirmed my reasons for coming to Yale and was a reminder of just how incredible the quality of education can be here. Wins the prize for best and coolest Prof/TA/Student combination of any course I've taken--grad students bring PhD level information to discussion, and some grad art students even created original works based on the absolute MASTERPIECES we watched. Also, Moira's totally unique critique of the movies was almost life-changingly interesting.
If you enjoy film and want to explore the films on the syllabus then yes
As long as it's taught in person and is not larger than 24 students, then yes.
If you are interested in watching lots of films from a wide list of cinematic history, yes.

Yes but do note that many of the films are slow however they are very good and have a wide variety. Most of the class is discussing the movies in sections. The main source of learning was meant to be done in intro to film and this is a class to put it into practice and learn from how other students put it into practice.
Only if you have to take it for the major requirement or already have a strong interest in film analysis.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom seminars.
Each week, a certain number of groups would have to meet prior to weekly class in order to prepare for a presentation.
None
None
Large virtual discussion lecture
Na
We also were able to meet with TAs and our classmates via Zoom to discuss the content of class.
Group presentations, asynchronatic self film viewings
N/A
Small group meetings outside of scheduled class time to prepare presentations
